itemDescription: British recipient of the Victoria Cross

wikipedia_page.main: John Scott Youll VC (6 June 1897 – 27 October 1918) was a British recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces.

response: It was planned to return the division to the plateau on 19 May, for an offensive timed for mid June, on the march back men began to fall sick with influenza, which swept through the division over the next few weeks.Sandilands p. 248 Back on the plateau, early June saw raiding of the Austrian lines, when it was learned that the Austrians planned their own offensive for 14 June. After bombarding only the front lines, the Austrian advance was stopped on the 68th Brigade front after three hours by rifle and machine gun fire, here Lt. Jack Youll of 11th Northumberland Fusiliers won the V.C. securing the junction between the 23rd and 48th divisions.Sandilands p. 253–258 To their left the 70th Brigade's front line was partly overrun, it was restored by headquarters details and some Italian trench mortar-men led by Lt. Col. Charles Hudson of the 11th Sherwood Foresters for which he received the V.C.Sandilands pp. 259–261 Further Austrian assaults were broken up by artillery.Sandilands pp. 262–263
* Jack Youll (18971918), English recipient of the Victoria Cross
:— Jack Youll , British Army officer (27 October 1918), prior to being killed in action at the Battle of Vittorio Veneto during World War I
